ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor?
The primary instructor's sensitivity to students and ability to provide students with adequate feedback was:

narratives.question_text: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course:
comments: Very reasonable!
5-10 hours/week, the reading responses often took a fair amount of time.
7 - for weekly readings and reading responses, more around midterm and final paper
~5-7 (with weekly summaries, more when there was a paper due)
For reading responses, I would say 1 hour per week. For the group paper and individual paper, I would say total about 4-7 days each?

narratives.question_text: Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved?
comments: Great course overall that further garnered my interest in global NCDs. Having a variety of speakers and lectures also allowed for more diverse learning content. There could have been clearer instruction/expectations for projects, however, maybe through the form of a rubric that students can refer to.
All around very well organized, interesting content, and comprehensive. All the assignments were good reflections of the material taught.
strengths: the professor, topic is very important

One of the best courses I have taken at YSPH. Nicky is a gem. Brilliant, approachable, funny, engaging...I left class feeling so empowered. My ideas felt like they were valued and I loved that the small class size allowed us all to get to know one another and each other's interests. It was my favorite course of the semester.

This class is wonderful. It is well organized, with a deliberate and clear purpose for each class. Professor Hawley could not be a more skilled lecturer or professor. She provides insightful comments on all work and fosters a very engaging, fun and supportive in class environment. I cannot say enough good things about this class.
Dr. Hawley is an amazing instructor who really cares about the students and their individual interest. A very important topic also! A class all people interested in global health should take!

Although a bit basic, this class is a good introduction to the world of global NCDs. The first few classes are a bit slow, but the class picks up when we get to the units that address how to reduce the burden of global NCDs. The guest speakers were fantastic! I do wish we had fewer reading responses, as they were quite time-consuming.
Excellent introduction to non-communicate disease with a global focus.
Strengths: Great discussions, many various topics in global health covered Weaknesses: Summaries may take a long time

narratives.question_text: Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
comments: Instructor: Nicola Hawley  Incredible professor who provided ample feedback and was always willing to help students learn about course content
Instructor: Nicola Hawley  AMAZING professor! Loved her energy and interest in the topic, provided great informational sessions and really set up the course very well.
Instructor: Nicola Hawley  Nicky is a wonderful professor who clearly cares about her students and fostering honest and critical discussion about the NCD landscape
Instructor: Nicola Hawley  Nicky Hawley is amazing and I wish every professor at YSPH was like her. Seriously, take her course you won't regret it.

Instructor: Nicola Hawley  Professor Hawley is excellent, certainly one of the best professors I have had at YSPH. She is extremely caring and wants her students to succeed. She provides copious comments on all students' work and is willing to go above and beyond to make sure her students are getting the help and information they need. Incredible, I feel very luck to have had the opportunity to take this class with her.
Instructor: Nicola Hawley  Dr. Hawley is an awesome instructor! Only positive things to say! She makes herself very available to the students and helps foster their interest!
Instructor: Nicola Hawley  Nicky is great! She is patient and receptive to feedback and welcomes any and all opinions on the material.
Instructor: Nicola Hawley  Very passionate and knowledgeable about NCDs. Always available to answer student questions and provide guidance.
Instructor: Nicola Hawley  Really nice! Gives great feedback! Great discussions during class
Instructor: Nicola Hawley  She's super enthusiastic, inspirational and approachable. Even if you don't take her class, I would recommend everyone to meet with her at least once!

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize this course for a fellow student? Would you recommend it to another student? Why or why not?
comments: Overall, a great course for those interested in global NCDs without a lot of background knowledge

Would absolutely recommend! Only comment, I think it would be a good assignment to have the different sections of the final paper due at different increments during the semester. Then after feedback, a final culmination of the paper edited and possibly with a last section not previously written. would be a good timeline.
NCDs are an increasingly critical topic in the health space - anyone interested in health should take this class!

This class covers a range of topics within global NCDs. The first half of the class is spent learning about the main NCDs and their risk factors. The second half is spent learning about potential interventions and solutions. It is well organized and extremely well taught. My favorite class at YSPH. I would recommend it to every student, regardless of concentration.
I would absolutely recommend this course! NCDs are too often forgotten about in global health and this class is important for learning about them and thinking about what can be done in the future.
Excellent introduction to non-communicate disease with a global focus.
Really interesting. Much more policy focused than epidemiology focused.
Take it!!! Also the class could use more males.
